beats.label: THE COURSE
beats.narration: Lost River Classic. Mathias, West Virginia. 85 mi. The Lost River Classic is Appalachian gravel distilled: constant elevation change through George Washington National Forest roads with no flat recovery sections. You're either grinding uphill on loose gravel or managing rocky descents that punish lapses in attention. The 85-mile course accumulates 8.5 thousand feet via repeated moderate climbs rather than single dramatic ascents. Rocky, rutted descents with embedded rocks demand strong bike handling even when legs are cooked. Remote backcountry sections deliver genuine adventure feel with limited cell service and sparse support. This isn't a race with signature viewpoints or Instagrammable moments. It's 85 miles of honest work where heat management matters more than power output.
beats.text_on_screen: Lost River Classic | Mathias, West Virginia | 85 mi
beats.editing_note: Let the course breathe. Show the route map, then cut to terrain-specific B-roll. This is the SETUP phase — grounding the viewer before the data analysis. Pacing: 25-40 sec cuts.

beats.label: STRENGTHS
beats.narration: What Lost River Classic does well.
beats.visual: Strengths list overlay with positive visual treatment
beats.editing_note: Warm energy. Each strength gets its own card. Avatar genuinely positive.

strengths: Legitimate elevation challenge (8,500 ft over 85 mi) tests climbing endurance
Technical terrain demands strong bike handling and rewards skill development
Benefits Lost River Trails Coalition—racing with purpose beyond personal glory
Grassroots community vibe with genuine local support and WV Gravel Series camaraderie
Excellent value: $65-85 for challenging course and trail advocacy contribution

beats.label: WEAKNESSES
beats.narration: What they don't put on the website.
beats.visual: Weaknesses list with warning visual treatment
beats.editing_note: MIDPOINT RE-ENGAGEMENT. This is ~55% through. Open with burst sequence (quick cuts, warning sounds). Then deliver weaknesses honestly. Preview what's coming: 'Now, should you actually do this race?'

weaknesses: August heat + humidity creates serious heat management challenge; not beginner-friendly climate
30-mile aid station gaps require genuine self-sufficiency; no hand-holding
Rural location (2 hrs from Dulles) with limited lodging requires advance planning
Limited national recognition means small field and minimal competitive depth
Spotty cell service and remote sections—if you need constant safety net, skip it

beats.label: LOGISTICS
beats.editing_note: Utility section. Lower energy, practical value. Hybrid Tempo: alternate fast logistics items (10-15 sec) with slow map visuals (30 sec).

logistics: Fly into: IAD - 2hr drive. PIT - 2.5hr north. Rental car mandatory.

Lodging: Mathias has minimal lodging. Book Moorefield, WV for motels/inns or Wardensville, WV. Lost River State Park cabins require months-advance reservation. Camping available at state park or George Washington National Forest sites. Plan ahead. this is rural WV, not a resort town.

beats.label: VERDICT
beats.narration: Verdict: Honest Appalachian Grinder. You need legitimate climbing fitness and wide-range gearing for the constant Appalachian rollers. August heat plus humidity makes this harder than the elevation suggests, and the rocky technical descents will punish weak bike handling. Show up undertrained and you'll be walking plenty of those punchy climbs in the remote backcountry sections.
beats.editing_note: CLOSE THE MAIN LOOP. 0.5s silence before verdict. Tier badge slams in. Avatar delivers final take. DO NOT signal 'wrapping up' — maintain energy.

beats.label: ALTERNATIVES
beats.narration: If Lost River Classic isn't quite right for you. Dirty Kanza offers similar distance with less technical terrain but more exposure, while Vermont Overland delivers comparable elevation with better logistics and cooler weather. Both have actual prestige and post-race scenes worth the travel cost.
